loans.name: Sikimbilo Shg Group

texts.en:
Cleophas is the facilitator of the Sikimbilo SHG group. Cleophas and his group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Cleophas takes care of three children at home. He joined One Acre Fund due to One Acre Fund’s best prices and in order to ensure food security for his family. In the recent 2011 season, Cleophas had a very good maize yield harvesting 12 bags on ½ an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund,  Cleophas was only able to harvest 4 bags of maize on ½  acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Cleophas and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Cleophas will educate his children.

In 2012, the members of Sikimbilo SHG group will each plant maize plots of between ½ and 1 acre of land.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Prisca

texts.en:
Prisca 31, is a mother of one child who attends school. She lives at a rental house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food, rent bills, and clothing.

For the past three years, she has operated a bananas selling business, selling at the market to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a challenge of stiff competition from other banana sellers in the area. Prisca dreams of expanding her business to earn more income in the future.

With the Kshs 50,000 she wants to construct her house, purchase construction materials, cement, sand, and pay for labor. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase construction materials, cement, sand and pay for labor.

loans.name: Lay

texts.en:
Mrs. Lay is a 39-year-old married woman who is in the business of cultivating rice crops in the Ornlong Veng district, Siem Reap province. In addition, she is a plastic kindling maker at home. She typically earns an average of $5.00 per day to cover the household needs through the two businesses. Presently, she has 3 single children who depend on her income and are attending school so she has to try hard to pay for their allowances and education. 

With the loan of $1,000, she’ll buy some spare parts to replace the broken ones in her plowing machine. With the remaining funds, she will purchase a trailer that can be used to connect to the back of the plowing machine in order to transport heavy things from place to place. This loan will make it possible for her to sustain her farming business. She is very grateful to all lenders.

loans.use: to buy some spare parts to replace the broken ones in her plowing machine.

loans.name: Salamatu

texts.en: This is 38-year-old Salamatu. She is married, and has 3 children, ages 21, 18 and 14 years. In 1999, Salamatu established her rubbers, clothes and slippers business. She began her business because she was trained in business. Working 6 days a week and 10 hours a day, she earns about 1,100,000 SLL every month from this business. She would like a loan in the amount of 3,000,000 SLL. Salamatu requires a loan in order to buy more plastic, clothing and slippers for her business. In the future, Salamatu plans to open her business in another area in the city and build her own house.   She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: to buy more plastic, clothing and slippers for her business

loans.name: Hok

texts.en:
Hok is 30 years old and a loving mother of two children. She is a rice cultivator from Ornlong Veng district, Siem Reap province. 

Currently, the profit from farming and from her husband is rarely enough to satisfy the family’s needs. 

In order to create more income, she intends to buy rice products from local farmers at a low price to stock after they harvest their rice during this season. Then she’ll resell it  when the market price of rice increases. It will produce a good profit for her family. 

What she really needs is capital; therefore, she is seeking for a loan from Kiva to buy stocks of rice to store up in her own house for future sale. 

She hopes to expand her business and send her two children to university after they finish high school.

loans.use: to buy stocks of rice to store up in her own house for the future sale.

loans.name: Dexter

texts.en:
Dexter is 40 years old and engaged in the farming business. He was blessed with three children who are currently in school. He needs to work hard in his business to yield a better income for their studies.

Due to financial constraints, he is asking for a loan of 20,000 PHP to buy corn seeds, fertilizers, and pesticides to improve his farming business. He hopes that this loan will help him develop his business in order to save for the future of his children, as well as improve their poor living standards.

loans.use: to buy corn seeds, fertilizers, and pesticides to improve his farming business

loans.name: Saumu

texts.en:
Saumu 48, is a married woman with five children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past ten years, she has operated a fish-selling business, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. She faces competition from other fish sellers in the area. 

In addition, she also operates a mahamri (dumplings) selling business, which contributes another source of income. 

With the KES 50,000, she wants to purchase sand and cement to construct her house and purchase wheat flour and cooking oil for her business. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sand and cement to construct her house and purchase wheat flour and cooking oil for her business.

loans.name: Gevorg

texts.en:
Gevorg is a young farmer from Sisian. He lives together with his wife and two sons, who always help him with agriculture. 

Gevorg keeps cattle and cultivates potatos and beans. Gevorg's cuurent income isn't sufficient to purchase forage for the cattle. This loan will allow Gevorg to sustain the cattle with necessary forage during winter season. Gevorg will receive enough income to sustain his family in prosperous conditions and develop his farm in the future.

loans.use: to pay for forage for his cattle.

loans.name: Anush

texts.en:
Anush lives together with her husband, daughter, mother-in-law and father-in-law.

Anush is engaged in farming. The current income Anush gets doesn't allow her to expand her farm. Thus she has applied for a loan. 

With the requested loan, Anush plans to purchase livestock. With the help of this loan, Anush will get enough income to meet the her family's needs and insure a sustainable future for them.

loans.use: to purchase livestock.

loans.name: Moussa

texts.fr:
Moussa est un tailleur qui  exerce le métier depuis 11 ans. I l est  marié et père de trois enfants.
Son activité consiste à acheter des tissus  à la mode, à les coudre pour les mettre dans le marché.
Avec le crédit il envisage d’acheter des tissus et de la garniture. Il s’occupe de sa famille et de leur besoin au quotidien.
Elargir son activité ,fait parti des plus grand projets de Moussa.
texts.en: Moussa has been working as a tailor for the past 11 years. He is a married father of three children. His business consists of purchasing fashionable fabric to sew together and put on the market. With this loan he will buy fabric and lining. He takes care of his family and their daily needs. Growing his business, is part of Moussa's larger plan.

loans.use: to purchase fabric and raw materials to sew together for resale.

loans.name: Hawa

texts.en:
This is 46-year-old Hawa. She is divorced and has four children, age 27, 18, 7 and years. She has two additional dependents who live with her because she assists them with their schooling.  

In 1990, Hawa established her palm oil and gari business. (Gari is a couscous-like food made from cassava.)

She began her business because she was not educated and she needed a reliable source of income to help her husband provide a livelihood for their family. Working six days a week and 10 hours a day, she earns about  1,300,000 SLL every month from this business. 

She would like a loan in the amount of 3,000,000 SLL. Hawa requires a loan in order to buy more stock of palm oil and gari for her business. In the future, Hawa plans to build more houses and give her children a quality education. She thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy more stock of palm oil and gari for her business.

loans.name: Anahit

texts.en:
Anahit lives together with her husband and three little children.  

She is engaged in agriculture. Due to her hard work and patience, Anahit has increased the number of the cattle she has from four to eight during the past few years. 

Now Anahit plans to develop the farm further. With the requested loan, she plans to purchase livestock and beehives. Development of farming will allow Anahit to increase her income and improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: to pay for livestock and beehives.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase bundles of clothes for resale.

loans.name: Tereza

texts.en:
Tereza lives together with her husband and children. 

Tereza is engaged in agriculture. She keeps livestock and cultivates land. 

Tereza needs a loan to increase the number of cattle. With the requested loan, she plans to purchase calves. This loan will help Tereza to develop farming and insure higher living standards for her family.

loans.use: to buy calves.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase sacks of green vegetables and tomatoes for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase seeds and fertilizer for a market garden.

loans.name: Wesakulila Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Wesakulila Group in Western Kenya! Fridah is the facilitator of the Wesakulila group. This  group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Fridah takes care of nine children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Fridah had a very good maize yield harvesting 16 bags on 1 acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Fridah was only able to harvest 4 bags of maize on 1 acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Fridah and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Fridah will educate her children and save for the future.

In 2012, the members of Wesakulila group will each plant  between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

The photograph shows Fridah with her group members.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Fadia

texts.en:
Fadia is a 47-year-old married woman and mother of two children. They represent her whole life.

Fadia lives a hard life; her husband travelled away a long time ago and left her responsible for two little children. She has to provide them with a suitable education and healthy living.

Fadia is a hairdresser and makeup artist, known for her excellent customer service. She works hard to develop her business; she intends to do so by buying a new cosmetics collection and that’s why she is requesting a loan from Kiva partner Al Majmoua.

Fadia has been an Al Majmoua borrower for five consecutive loan cycles, which reflected positively on her social and financial situation. She also started to rent wedding dresses as an extra business, which leads to extra income.

Fadia is an excellent borrower with a very good paying-back history. She is a woman with a good reputation. Fadia is a social, lovely and patient woman, always looking towards achieving more success in her business future.

loans.use: to increase her cosmetics supply and wedding dresses

loans.name: Zamira

texts.ru: Замирахон замужем и у нее трое детей. Муж занимается разным бизнесом и одновременно работает в рыболовном хозяйстве.Он содержит семью, а Замирахон занимается торговлей детской одеждой. Это приносит дополнительный доход, который она тратит на своих детей. Она начала свой биснес в 2003 году. С нашей организацией сотрудничает более 6-ти лет. Первая сумма кредита составляла 300 сомони и с каждым разом расширяя свой бизнес у нее увеличивалась и сумма кредита. Последняя сумма кредита составляло 1000 сомони. На эту сумму она планирует закупить зимний ассортимент.
texts.en: Zamirahon is married and has three children.  Her husband is involved in various type of business and works in the fishing sector at the same time.  He support the family, and Zamirahon is involved in sales of children's clothing.  This brings in an additional income, which she spends on her children.  She started her business in 2003.  Zamirahon has been working with our organization for over six years.  Her first loan was 300 somoni, and as her business grew with every loan, so did the loan amount.  Her last loan was 1000 somoni.  She plans to use this loan to purchase a winter selection of merchandise.

loans.use: to purchase a winter selection of merchandise

loans.name: Patrick

texts.en:
Patrick is a farmer in Kitale and is married with 2 children aged 9 and 5 years. He has been in farming for 5 years producing and selling milk, eggs and maize to the local market.

Patrick has requested a loan of 101,200 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow at 31,200 KES and buy poultry birds at 70,000 KES. He says the two purchases will boost his farming business. He says he hopes to have four dairy cows to earn him more income for his family's upkeep.

He laments about the high costs of feed, especially during dry seasons.

loans.use: to buy poultry birds and a dairy cow

loans.name: Musa

texts.en:
Musa is 35 years old and has been in farming for 8 years. He is married with 4 children aged between 10 and 1 years. He currently employs one farmhand and produces milk, eggs and maize for the local market. He works as a veterinary officer in Kitale.

Musa has requested a loan of 102,400 KES from Juhudi Kilimo. He says he will use 62,400 KES to buy and insure a dairy cow and use the remaining 40,000 KES to construct a modern dairy unit (barn) for his animals. He hopes the developments will boost his production to the level that he generates more income for better family upkeep and education for the children.

He notes animal diseases as the main challenge in farming.

loans.use: to buy and insure a dairy cow and construct a dairy unit

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase sacks of mangoes

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David is a resident farmer in Kitale, Western Kenya. He is 54 years old and married with 8 children, seven of whom are still attending school. He has been in farming for 10 years and currently produces milk, maize and eggs for the local market.

David has made a loan request with Juhudi Kilimo for 31,200 KES, this being his second loan request. He says he will use the loan to buy and insure a dairy cow. He hopes his milk production will improve and the family will have more milk for consumption as well as generate more income.

However, he laments the high cost of feed and animal diseases.

loans.use: to buy and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Tuhfa

texts.ru: Тухфа  сотрудничает с нашей организацией  более 7 лет. Первый кредит получала на ларек возле своего дома. Сейчас она имеет 2 точки продажи женского материала и одежды. Живет одна, муж уехал на заработки 15 лет назад и не вернулся. В бизнесе помогает внучка. Кроме это, того она работает в Университете преподавателем истории. В дни, когда она на работе в университете, внучка сидит и приглядывает за товаром, так она помогает своей бабушке. Тухфа сама за товаром ездить не может из-за здоровья и возраста, ей привозят товар знакомые или родственники.  Товар привозят с Киргизии в течении 4-5 дней.  На полученный кредит она собирается привезти теплую одежду - джемпера, халаты, а из тканей велюр, бархат и другие модные национальные ткани. Сейчас у нее сезон, так как перед новым годом будет хорошая реализация, женщины буду шить на праздники красивые платья.
texts.en: Tuhfa has been working with our organization for over seven years.  She received her first loan for a retail stand near her house.  Now, she has two retail outlets, where she sells women's fabrics and clothing.  She lives alone because her husband left for work 15 years ago and never returned.  Her granddaughter helps her with the business.  Besides this, Tuhfa works as a history teacher at the University.  During the days, when she works at the university, her granddaughter helps her grandmother.  Tuhfa cannot travel for merchandise herself due to her health and age, and her friends or relatives deliver merchandise to her.  They bring merchandise from Kyrgyzstan in 4-5 days.  Tuhfa plans to bring in warm clothing, such as sweaters and robes, and fabrics, such as velour, velvet and other stylish national fabrics.  Currently, this is a prime season for her business because sales will be good before the New Year's, since women will be sewing nice dresses for the holidays.

loans.use: to purchase warm clothing and fabrics

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase bales of cloth materials and hand bags.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase bundles of wheat flour and cooking-fat oil.

loans.name: Nadia

texts.en:
Nadia is a 46-year-old married woman, and the mother of five children. Taking the responsibility of raising five children is not an easy job at all, and not everyone can pass it successfully. But Nadia never failed a task; she works hard through selling olive oil and goats’ milk in addition to the cattle-breeding business.

Nadia's working schedule is too exhausting and long; she does so to provide the best life for her family. Although she’s very tired and sometimes she feels down because of life’s unexpected problems, you can always find the smile on her face.

Nadia never stops thinking of expanding her business. She decided to increase the number of goats she owns to increase milk production, and this will happen through a loan applied for from Kiva partner Al Majmoua.

Nadia had previous experience with Al Majmoua, and it was very impressive and reflected positively on her business.

Nadia is special in her customer care policy, and she cares a lot about the quality of products she sells. She cares a lot about her good reputation; she believes that "success has no limits," and she hopes to expand her work more through future loans to increase her cattle and to open a small milk production factory.

loans.use: To increase the number of goats she owns.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase firewood and start a charcoal business.

loans.name: Shushan

texts.en: Shushan is engaged in an agricultural business. She keeps cattle and cultivates land. The current number of livestock doesn't allow Shushan to meet her family's needs and cover the educational costs for her children. With the requested loan, Shushan plans to purchase livestock and forage. This loan will help Shushan to develop farming and ensure a sustainable future for her family. Shushan lives together with her husband and children. Besides her household and agriculture, Shushan is also an active member of her community. She is engaged in a group supporting women with their activities and main problems.

loans.use: to pay for livestock and forage

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase bundles of firewood and sacks of charcoal

loans.name: Narine

texts.en: Narine is a retailer from Artashat. She has been running the business for two years and has created all conditions to expand it. With the requested loan, Narine plans to purchase clothing for the winter season. This loan will help Narine to develop her business and gain more income. Additional income will allow Narine to ensure a prosperous life for her family. Narine lives together with her husband and children.

loans.use: to purchase clothing

loans.name: Jackline

texts.en:
Jackline has been selling hand bags for the last year and earns a monthly profit of KES 7,000. She is a single lady who is 28 years old.

She was introduced to KADET LTD by a friend and she has applied for her first loan of KES 30,000 from KADET LTD. She plans to use the loan amount to buy more stock of bags for sale.

The anticipated profits she will save and in the future, she hopes to open a boutique, grow her business and be financially stable.

loans.use: to buy more stock of bags for sale

loans.name: Sevelina

texts.en:
Sevelina is aged 31, single and a mother of 2 adult children. She has been in farming for 15 years with her produce of eggs going to the local market.

Sevelina has made a loan request with Juhudi Kilimo for 50,000 KES to help her boost her poultry business by buying more birds. She says this will boost her farming to large scale and allow her to enjoy the economies of this scale. She adds that her first loan with Juhudi Kilimo of a similar amount made life bearable and she remains optimistic about her future in farming and income in general. She notes, however, with regret, the high costs of feeds.

loans.use: to buy poultry birds

loans.name: Riziki

texts.en: Riziki is taking another Kiva loan of KES 60,000 to boost her clothes-selling business, as she anticipates an increase in demand during the festive season. With the loans, she wants to purchase bales of Kikois for resale. She dreams of expanding her business and establishing a boutique in the future.

loans.use: to purchase bales of Kikois for resale

loans.name: Armine

texts.en: Armine lives together with her husband. She is engaged in agriculture. Armine's husband is a butcher and also helps her with agriculture. Armine would like to expand her farm, but she doesn't have sufficient financial means. With the requested loan, Armine plans to purchase livestock and forage. This loan will help Armine to develop farming and increase her income. Additional income means higher living standards for Armine's family in the future.

loans.use: to pay for livestock and forage

loans.name: Douglas

texts.en:
Douglas is a father of four, with the youngest two being minors and still schooling. He is aged 51 and has practiced farming for 20 years. His farm currently supplies the local market with milk and coffee.

Douglas has requested a loan of 63,600 KES from Kiva partner Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He says he intends to use the farming income to educate his children. He adds that Juhudi Kilimo loans have helped many farmers with financial assistance.

Douglas laments of escalating costs of animal feed as his major challenge. He lives with his family in Murang'a, Central Kenya.

loans.use: to buy and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: David

texts.en:
David is aged 46 and has been active in farming in his home area of Nkubu, Central Kenya for 6 years, with his produce of bananas and milk being sold to the local market. He is married with three children aged 17, 13 and 4.

David has requested a loan of 30,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase irrigation pipes for his farming business, especially the bananas business. This is his second loan request after the first one of 45,000 KES. He says the loan will help boost his farming income and enable him to educate his children.

David laments over insufficient rainfalls and low prices for farming produce.

loans.use: to buy irrigation pipes

loans.name: Magdaline

texts.en:
Magdaline is a farmer and a mother of 4 children ages 16,11,9 and 6 and all in school. She is age 39 herself and has been in farming for 16 years with her farm currently producing maize, tobacco, bananas and beans which she sells to the local market. She also makes  and sells french fries in the local market.

Magdaline has requested for a loan of 45,000 KES through Juhudi Kilimo to help her buy piglets for a new venture into pig farming. She hopes the business will uplift her family living standards and provide finances to meet the needs of the children's education.This is her second loan with Juhudi Kilimo and she reiterates that the loan has improved her family's living standards.

Magdaline laments the high cost of farm inputs and insufficient rainfall.

loans.use: To buy piglets

loans.name: Mwanahawa

texts.en: Mwanahawa is taking a Kiva loan of KES 60,000 to boost her clothes selling business as she anticipates an increase in demand for clothes during the festive season. The previous loan had a lot of impact on her business as Mwanahawa's income increased by 50 percent. With the additional income she has provided enough food for her family.

loans.use: To purchase a bale of clothes for resale

loans.name: Hudson

texts.en:
Hudson is age 50. He is married with 8 children. Three are adults with the other five being minors still in school.
He has been in farming in his home area of Kitale,Western Kenya for five years producing and selling maize, milk, vegetables and tomatoes for the local market. 

Hudson has made a loan request amounting to 50,000 KES with Juhudi Kilimo to construct a greenhouse to use in growing tomatoes. He says this will boost his farming income with his supplies being stable throughout the year. He hopes to redouble his farming income especially that from tomatoes and vegetables in the near future.

Huddson notes that high costs of farm inputs coupled with animal diseases remain the major undoing in the farming business.

loans.use: To construct  a greenhouse

loans.name: Samiha

texts.en:
Samiha is a 52-year old married woman. She owns a small market for daily use products, in addition to baking Saj bread.
Samiha opened her store 11 years ago so she has had long experience in this business.  She seeks to improve her business through increasing the different types of goods she sells. She wants to add fireworks for Christmas and New Year’s celebrations. She will also start selling toys for children, which is a good step forward.That’s why she is requesting a loan from Kiva partner, Al Majmoua. 

Samiha is known for the good quality of products she sells, and good customer service. She aspires to give her customers better quality and prices with the help of the loan applied for, and through expanding her business more in the future.

loans.use: To increase her business merchandise

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Christine is 33 years old and lives in the town of Tororo in the Mbale region of Uganda. She is married and has six children with four of them currently in school. For the past five years, Christine has been working hard to manage her clothes store, which sells various kinds of clothes. 

To help expand her business, Christine has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more clothes for resale, and will help Christine to generate greater profits and improve her family's welfare. Christine hopes that in the future she will be able to open up another branch. 

Christine is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Christine who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more clothes for resale

loans.name: Sichinikhi Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Sichinikhi Group in Western Kenya! Leah is the facilitator of the Sichinikhi group. This  group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Leah takes care of four children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Leah had a very good maize yield harvesting 16 bags on 1 acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Leah was only able to harvest 2 bags of maize on 1 acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Leah and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Leah will educate her children, ensure food security and invest in livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Sichinikhi group will each plant  between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

The photograph shows Leah with her group members.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Bokoli Shg Group

texts.en:
Benard is the facilitator of the Bokoli SHG group. Benard and his group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Benard takes care of five children at home. He joined One Acre Fund due to One Acre Fund’s best prices and in order to ensure food security for his family and later educate them. In the recent 2011 season, Benard had a very good maize yield harvesting 9 bags on ½ an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund,  Benard was only able to harvest 4½ bags of maize on ½  acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Benard and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Benard will invest in livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Bokoli SHG group will each plant maize plots between ½ and 1 acre of land.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase weaves, a variety of hair chemicals, combs, braids, and hair oil for her cosmetic shop.

loans.name: Beam Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Beam Group in Western Kenya! Zipporah is the facilitator of the Beam  group. This  group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Zipporah takes care of two children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Zipporah had an excellent maize yield harvesting 18 bags on 1 acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Zipporah was only able to harvest 5 bags of maize on 1 acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Zipporah and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Zipporah will educate her children, ensure food security, and invest in livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Beam group will each plant  between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

The photograph shows Zipporah with her group members.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Kalukhila A Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Kalukhila A Group in Western Kenya! Hellen is the facilitator of the Kalukhila A group. This  group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Hellen takes care of nine children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Hellen had an excellent maize yield harvesting 21 bags on 1 acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Hellen was only able to harvest 6 bags of maize on 1 acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Hellen and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Hellen will educate her children.

In 2012, the members of Kalukhila A group will each plant  between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Marknaf

texts.en:
Marknaf has operated a medical clinic for the last seven years and earns a monthly profit of KES. 10,000. He is married to Christine, and they have two children.

He was introduced to KADET LTD by a friend and he has applied for his second loan of KES. 30,000 from KADET LTD. He plans to use the loan amount to pay school fees.

He will save the anticipated profits, and in the future he hopes to expand his business and be financially stable.

loans.use: to pay school fees.

loans.name: Chemwa Shg Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Chemwa SHG Group in Western Kenya! Frida is the facilitator of the Chemwa SHG group. This  group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Frida takes care of four children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Frida had an excellent maize yield harvesting 12 bags on 1 acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Frida was only able to harvest 4 bags of maize on 1 acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Frida and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Frida will educate her children and save for the future.

In 2012, the members of Chemwa SHG group will each plant  between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

The photograph shows Frida with her group members.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Yayeri

texts.en:
Yayeri is 41 years old and lives in the town of Mityano in the Mubende region of Uganda. She is married and has three children with two of them currently in school. For the past eleven years, Yayeri has been working hard to manage her boutique, which sells second-hand clothing. 

To help expand her business, Yayeri has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more shirts and children's wear, and will help Yayeri to generate greater profits and pay her children's school fees. Yayeri hopes that in the future she will be able to open another outlet for second-hand clothes. 

Yayeri is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Yayeri who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase more shirts and children's wear

loans.name: Paul

texts.en:
Paul is a 52 year old business man. He is married to Jane who is a farmer. They are blessed with two children aged 21 and 19 years respectively. He has been running a butcher shop for the past three years and receives monthly income of KES 15,000 which he uses to support his family.

He is applying for his third loan term from KADET LTD after repaying the previous loans successfully. Paul will use the loan to buy a bull to slaughter for his business. 

With the anticipated profit from the business he will educate his children. His hopes and dreams are to open a retail shop which will increase his income.

loans.use: To buy a bull for his butcher business.

loans.name: Constance

texts.en:
Constance is a married woman with three children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past five years, she has operated a clothes selling business selling from door to door to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of price fluctuations in her business. For the future. she dreams of establishing a shop to sell her clothes.

With the Kshs 10,000 she wants to purchase bundles of clothes for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of clothes for resale.

loans.name: Ahamedi

texts.en:
Ahamedi is 38 years old and lives in the town of Mityano in the Mubende region of Uganda. He is married and has two children--one of them currently in school. For the past seven years, Ahamedi has been working hard to manage his small shop, which sells second-hand shoes. 

To help expand his business, Ahamedi has requested a loan of 2,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more women's and children's shoes, and will help Ahamedi to generate greater profits and buy a larger variety of shoes. Ahamedi hopes that in the future he will be able to open up other outlets for shoe sales. 

Ahamedi is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Ahamedi who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase more women's and children's shoes for resale.

loans.name: Nelson

texts.en:
Nelson has been in farming for 15 years in his hometown of Kitale, Western Kenya producing and selling maize and vegetables. He is married with five children who ages are between 17 and 6 years old. He carries out a cereals retail business in the local market for additional income. He is aged 46.

Nelson has requested a loan of 80,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo. This is his third loan request with Juhudi Kilimo. He says he will use the loan to venture into poultry farming by buying poultry and constructing a poultry unit. He says he hopes to build the business and focus on being the main supplier of eggs to the supermarkets in the local markets.

He says the challenge is poultry feeds which have become expensive.

loans.use: To buy poultry and construct a poultry unit for farming.

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes is a mother of five children. Two of the children are still schooling and the rest are adults. She is aged 43 and has been active in farming for 10 solid years selling farm produce such as maize, milk and vegetables to the local market.

Agnes has requested a loan of 52,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. She says the acquisition of an additional dairy cow will boost her farming income and enable her to advance her farming business with a modern zero grazing unit as well as buy better breeds of animals.

She laments the high costs of farming inputs and unreliable rainfalls.

loans.use: To buy and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Caroline

texts.en:
Caroline is a married woman who lives in a rental house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and rental bills.

For the past 2 years, she has operated a boutique business, selling to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge with the high cost of transporting goods from Mombasa to her place of operation. She dreams of establishing a big boutique shop in the future.

With the loan of KES 20,000, she wants to purchase bales of clothes, shoes, and hand bags. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bales of clothes, shoes, and hand bags.

loans.name: Willypaforce

texts.en:
Willyparforce has been in the business of mixed farming for 5 years in his home area of Kitale, Western Kenya producing and selling maize, cabbage, and milk to the local market. He is married with one child aged 1 year old.

Willypaforce has requested a loan of 30,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to be able to construct a dairy unit at 10,000 KES and to buy poultry birds at 20,000 KES. He says his improved farming will enhance his financial security and he hopes to manage the business to propel him to the status of large scale farmer, especially with the poultry business.

However, he mentions animal diseases and the high cost of feed as challenges.

loans.use: To construct a  dairy unit and poultry birds.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy clothing material

loans.name: Bokoli Rural Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Bokoli Rural Group in Western Kenya! Doris is the facilitator of the Bokoli Rural group. This  group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Doris takes care of seven children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Doris had a very good maize yield harvesting 15 bags on 1 acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Doris was only able to harvest 5 bags of maize on 1 acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Doris  and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Doris will educate her children.

In 2012, the members of Bokoli Rural group will each plant  between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James is 34 years old and married with 4 children aged between 10 and 4 years. He has been in active farming for 3 years, with his produce of maize, eggs and beans being sold to the local market. He lives with his family in Kitale, Western Kenya.

James has requested a loan of 31,200 KES from Kiva partner Juhudi Kilimo to buy and insure a dairy cow. He says the dairy cow will improve his farming income, and he intends to buy a motorcycle with the farming income for a venture into a transport business. He adds there will be more milk, too, for family consumption

James says animal diseases are a challenge to farmers in the area.

loans.use: to buy and insure a dairy cow

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy matemba (small dried fish) and sugar beans in bulk

loans.name: Moses

texts.en:
Moses is 49 years old and lives in the town of Mityana in the Mubende region of Uganda. He is married and has three children. For the past eight years, Moses has been working hard to manage his pharmacy, which provides medicine and treatment to local patients. 

To help expand his business, Moses has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more medicine for resale and will help Moses to generate greater profits to pay school fees and medical expenses for his family. Moses hopes that in the future he will be able to open a bigger drug shop in town.

Moses is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Moses who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase more medicine for resale

loans.name: Rosemary

texts.en:
Rosemary is a married woman with two children, both of whom attend school. She owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past five years, she has operated a retail shop business, selling to her neighbours and passersby. In addition, she also owns a clearance and forwarding (shipping) company from which she earns her other source of income. 

With the 20,000 KES she wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour and sugar for her retail shop business. She dreams of expanding her clearance and forwarding firm in the future.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour and sugar for her retail shop business

loans.name: Juliette

texts.fr:
Cliente de 43 ans, celibataire avec 5 enfants a sa charge dont l'age varie entre 7 et 24 ans, elle se lance dans l'alimentation il y'a de cela 20 ans quand elle se sépare avec son mari, et elle se sent abandonne avec une lourde responsabilité de s'occuper de ses enfants.

Ayant deja bénéficie de plusieurs prêts de Hope, elle a assure les frais d'écolage de ses enfants, elle a épargne avec succès et a rembourse sans difficultés, sa vie sociale et économique a entièrement changée.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, elle va renforcer le stock de ses marchandises en ajoutant des cartons de tomates pelées, des cartons de cassoulets, des cartons de macédoines, petits pois et toutes les articles qui attirent les clients.
A l'avenir elle est entrain de continuer a épargner et avec ses benefices elle veut construire une boutique pour laisser l'étalage du marche et tient fermement a amener ses enfants a faire des longues etudes.
texts.en:
This client is forty-three years old, single, and has five children between the ages of seven and 24 in her care. She began in the food business 20 years ago when she and her husband separated and she was abandoned with the great responsibility of taking care of her children.

She has already benefited from several HOPE loans.  She has been able to pay for her children's education, to successfully save money and payback loans without difficulty.  Her social and economic life has completely changed.

With this new loan she will increase the stock of her merchandise by adding boxes of peeled tomatoes, cassoulet [meat and bean stew], fruit and vegetable salads, peas, and all the items that attract clients. 

In the future she will continue to save money and with her profits she would like to build a shop so she can move from her stall at the market. She believes strongly in encouraging her children stay in school a long time.

loans.use: to buy boxes of canned goods such as peeled tomatoes, fruit and vegetable salads, sweetcorn, and dried sausages.

loans.name: Gohar

texts.en: Gohar trades in washing supplies. With the income from her current business, Gohar isn't able to cover her family's costs. So she would like to enlarge her business. With the requested loan, Gohar plans to purchase more washing supplies to sell. An increase in sales will allow Gohar to get more income and ensure a better future for her family. Gohar lives with her husband and two children.

loans.use: to pay for washing supplies.

loans.name: Betty

texts.en: Betty lives in Uganda.  She is married and has three children, all of whom are in school. She doesn't take care of additional family members. Betty has a business of selling fabrics of Bitenge (African style fabric) and other materials. She has been in this business for four years, and she works six days out of every week. Betty sells her products in a shop, by means of wholesale. Betty has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more rolls of Bitenge and other fabrics. The main business challenges for Betty include defaulters and thieves. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to start importing fabrics from the Democratic of Congo and also to build her own house. Betty lives in a home that she rents; she has access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include rent, school fees, and feeding the family.

loans.use: to buy more rolls of fabric and other materilas for making clothes

loans.name: Aisha

texts.en:
Aisha is a widowed woman with five children, all of whom are grown-ups. She owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past year, she has operated a juice selling business and charcoal business, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. In addition, she also owns residential houses which contribute to her income. She faces a major challenge of the high cost of transporting charcoal to her place of operation. 

With the Kshs 40,000 she wants to renovate her residential houses and purchase charcoal for sale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to renovate her residential houses and purchase charcoal for sale.

loans.name: Robinah

texts.en:
Robinah is 26 years old and lives in the town of Kisekende in the Mubende region of Uganda. She is married and has one child who is currently in school. For the past 4 years, Robinah has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells food and home supplies to local customers. 

To help expand her business, Robinah has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more coffee for resale and will help Robinah to generate greater profits and pay medical expenses and rent. Robinah hopes that in the future she will be able to transform her business from a retail shop to a big wholesale shop. 

Robinah is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Robinah who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase more coffee for resale.

loans.name: Edith

texts.en:
Edith lives in Kampala, Uganda.  She is single and has 5 children, two of whom are in school.  She also takes care of additional family members (3 grandchildren).  Edith  has a business selling charcoal.  She has been in this business for 6 years, and she works 7 days every week.  Edith sells her products from home, by means of retail. She has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bags of charcoal. She also generates additional income through rental rooms. 

The main business challenge(s) for Edith includes defaulters and the increasing price of charcoal. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to become a wholesaler and to build more rentals houses. Edith lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees, medication, and feeding the family.

loans.use: to buy more bags of charcoal.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice, 29, is a married woman who lives at a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are rent bills and food for the family.

For the past three years, she has operated a cereals business, selling in a shop to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her place of operation. Her major dream is to expand her business in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase sacks of cereals, beans, and green grains. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of cereals, beans, and green grains.

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph is 25 years old and lives in the town of Mubende in Uganda. He works hard to manage his small shop, which sells mobile phones, phone accessories, and other electronics. 

To help expand his business, Joseph has requested a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more phones for resale, and will help Joseph to generate greater profits and improve his family's standard of living. Joseph hopes that in the future he will be able to construct a house. 

Joseph is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Joseph who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase more phones for resale.

loans.name: Caroline

texts.en:
Caroline 24, is a single woman, with one child who attends school. She lives at a rental house that has electricity and piped water. Her biggest monthly expenses are food, rent bills and school fees.

For the past six months, she has operated a vegetable stall business, selling to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. Caroline dreams of expanding her business to meet her customer's demand in the future.

With the Kshs 10,000 she wants to purchase bundles of vegetables, tomatoes, onions and fruits. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase inventory of tomatoes, onions and other fruits and vegetables for her stall.

loans.name: Sylvia

texts.en:
Sylvia  lives in  Kampala, Uganda.  She is single and has 5 children, three of whom are in school.  She also takes care of additional family members (2 grand children). Sylvia has a business of selling charcoal.  She has been in this business for 1 year, and work 7 day/ week.  

Sylvia sells her products at the market.  She has requested a loan of 2000000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more  bags of charcoal.  She also generates additional income through a small retail shop .The main business challenges for Sylvia includes transportation and increasing prices of charcoal.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to become a wholesaler, and also build more build rental houses. Sylvia lives in a home that she owns.  She has access to electricity and piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include school fees, medication and feeding the family.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Nicolas

texts.en:
Nicolas is a 27-year-old Lebanese married man living with his wife and only one child. He’s the one responsible for his family and seeks to offer them a better future.  He opened his own bakery in 2005, and looks forward to growing his business. 

Today, he needs to borrow $1500 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l to purchase raw materials for his business - items such as oil, flour, soft drinks and more. This Kiva loan will facilitate his work and boost his productivity.  In future, he plans to buy a van and deliver bread to the nearby villages.

loans.use: to purchase raw materials such as oil, flour, soft drinks etc. for his business.

loans.name: Munaa

texts.en:
Munaa 30, is a married woman with three children, all of whom attend school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and rent bills.

For the past two years, she has been operating a cosmetic shop, selling to her local area residents. She faces a major challenge with fluctuation in prices of her products. Munaa dreams of expanding her business in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase cosmetics for her shop. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase cosmetics for her shop.

loans.name: Phillip

texts.en:
Phillip is a 34-year-old businessman who lives in Juba. He is married and has one child who is 5 months old.
 
Phillip runs a tailoring business. He has been in the business for five years and has no employees. Phillip heard about Finance Sudan from the loan officers’ promotion done in the market. He is taking a loan of 2,000 SDG to purchase items like cloth and some spare parts for the sewing machine. Besides this business, Phillip has no other source of income. 

In five years time, Phillip would like to hope for a better future like having two sewing machines so that he can create employment opportunities for others.
 
His major challenges include his low income, the high cost of living, and the expensiveness of items in the market.

Phillip says that he appreciates Finance Sudan for its support in helping his business grow.

loans.use: to purchase items like cloth and some spare parts for the sewing machine.

loans.name: Juan Sebastiani

texts.es:
Juan es socio nuevo en el banco comunal “Chaska” y sus amigos le invitaron en participar en el banco comunal. 

Juan nació en la ciudad de Lima, tiene 40 años de edad y tiene una relación de unión libre de la cual tiene un hijo. Desde varios años que Juan vive en la ciudad del Cusco donde realiza sus actividades económicas. Juan se dedica a brindar servicio de taxi en el carro que alquila de su primo, él tiene que pagar por el alquilar del carro s/. 30 nuevos soles por 12 horas, él en esta oportunidad requiere el préstamo para hacer mantenimiento del carro. Su sueño de Juan es comprarse un carro.      

Juan agradece y valora el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas mensuales.
texts.en: Juan is a member of the “Chaska” communal bank; his friends invited him to participate in it.  Juan was born in the city of Lima.  He’s 40 years old and in a common law relationship; he has a son.  Juan has lived in the city of Cusco for several years and this is where he carries out his economic activities.  Juan provides taxi service in a car that he leases from his cousin.   He has to pay a fee of 30 soles for 12 hours.  On this occasion he needs the loan for car maintenance.  Juan’s dream is to buy a car of his own.  Juan is grateful for and values the loan and commits to make his monthly installment payments.

loans.use: to service his car.

loans.name: Ugul

texts.ru: Угул 1963 года рождения, преподаватель с высшим образованием, имеет 3х детей. Замужем, муж Рахимчон работает слесарем – востребованная профессия и его работа не имеет сезонности и имеет стабильный доход. В семье работает ещё сын в маслозаводе «Авангард». Клиентка сама работает в общеобразовательной школе преподавателем персидского языка и заведующей учебной частью. После информирования о программе кредитования в ее школе образовали группу солидарной ответственности в составе преподавателей из этой же школы, и с 2009 года начали кредитоваться в нашей организации. Этот кредит берет на потребительские цели, несколько раз уже использовала целенаправленно кредит, пользуется уважением среди коллег и имеет положительное кредитное досье. Стаж ее кредитования непрерывный и она рада, что сотрудничает с нами.
texts.en: Ugul was born in 1963.  She is a teacher with a higher education and has three children.  She is married, and her husband, Rahimchon, works as a mechanic, which is a highly-demanded, non-seasonal profession, that brings in a stable income.  Their son works at a butter plant, called Avangard.  Ugul herself works at a secondary school as a Persian language teacher and an assistant principal of studies.  After learning about the financing program, her school formed a solidarity group, consisting of teachers from this school, and started to obtain loans from our organization since 2009.  This loan is being obtained for consumer goals.  Ugul has previously used loans purposefully several times; she is respected among her colleagues and has a positive credit history.  Her loan history is continuous, and she is glad to be partnering with us.

loans.use: to achieve consumer goals

loans.name: Anyas

texts.en:
Anyas is a 23-year-old Lebanese single woman. She lives with her mother and two siblings. Her siblings are both working in addition to their mother, who is the one covering the family’s expenses. 

As for Anyas, she has been working as a private teacher for the past four years from her home. She is intelligent and expert in her field. Today she is asking for a loan of $800 from Kiva partner, Ameen s.a.l., to purchase a laptop for her business. She notes that this will allow her to develop her way of teaching and thus her communication with her students.
 
In the future, she plans to open her own learning center.

loans.use: to purchase a laptop for her business.

loans.name: Mikayel

texts.en:
Mikayel is engaged in agriculture. He lives together with his wife, mother, and children.
 
Mikayel needs some financial means to improve his orchard and protect it. With the requested loan he plans to purchase wire and columns. This will allow him to organize the cultivation of land, grow trees more effectively, and have a better harvest next year. 

Mikayel will increase his profit and improve his family's living conditions.

loans.use: to pay for wire and columns for the orchard.

loans.name: Lion Group

texts.en:
Moses is the facilitator of the Lion group. Moses and his group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Moses takes care of eight children at home. He joined One Acre Fund due to One Acre Fund’s best prices and in order to ensure food security for his family. In the recent 2011 season, Moses had a very good maize yield harvesting 8 bags on ½ an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund,  Moses was only able to harvest 3 bags of maize on ½  acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Moses and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Moses will educate his children.

In 2012, the members of Lion group will each plant maize plots of between ½ and 1 acre of land.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma, 38, is a married woman with three children, all of whom attend school. She lives at a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past two years, she has operated a business of selling shoes and clothes for resale. Her potential customers are neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. She dreams of expanding her business to a big stall in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000, she wants to purchase bales of clothes and shoes for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bales of clothes and shoes for resale.

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter is a 53 year-old businessman.  He is married to Lucia, who is a farmer. They are blessed with three children, aged 23, 21 and 18 years, respectively. He has been running a retail shop for the past nine years, with a monthly income of KES 20,000, which he uses to support his family.

He is applying for his second loan from KADET LTD, after repaying the previous loan successfully. Peter will use the loan to buy a stock of sugar, rice and wheat flour for his shop. 

With the anticipated profit, he will expand his business. His hopes and dreams are to open a wholesale shop which will improve the living standard of his family.

loans.use: To buy stock of sugar, rice and wheat flour for his shop

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is taking another Kiva loan of KES 40,000 to boost her business of clothes selling, and also to do plumbing.  With the loan, she intends to purchase bales of clothes and to install water pipes in her home. She dreams of expanding and taking a bigger loan in the future to meet her needs.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of clothes, and to do plumbing in her house.

loans.name: Logala

texts.en:
Logala, a 49-year-old businessman, lives in Juba where he is the married father of four children between the ages of 18 and 3, two of whom go to school. Logala, who has operated a tailoring business for 14 years, heard about Finance Sudan from promotions done by loan officers in the market. He is now requesting a loan of SDG2000 to purchase clothing items and materials.

Logala's major challenges include low income and high living costs, and he is very glad that Finance Sudan has opened up this opportunity in his country. As a result, he hopes for a better future.

loans.use: to purchase clothing items and materials.

loans.name: Roberto Antonio

texts.es:
Roberto, está solicitando nuevamente un préstamo, porque desea surtir el negocio con más productos, actualmente comprara maíz, cocos, ropa nueva (blusas, faldas, pantalones), también pescado fresco, toda esta mercadería es para ofrecer una diversidad a los clientes, generando más oportunidades de ganancias.
Él tuvo un efecto positivo con el préstamo anterior, ya que sus ventas han mejorado, la condición de su familia también ha mejorado.
texts.en: Roberto is asking for a loan once again because he wants to invest in his business with more products.  He will buy corn, coconuts, new clothes (blouses, skirts and pants) and also fresh fish.  All this merchandise is to offer a wider variety to his customers thereby generating more opportunity for profits.  He had a positive effect from his previous loan in that his sales have improved and so has his family’s condition.

loans.use: to buy corn, coconuts, clothes and fish.

loans.name: Ali Edson

texts.es:
Edson es socio nuevo en el banco comunal “Chaska” y sus amigos le invitaron en participar en el banco comunal. 

Edson nació en la ciudad de Cusco, tiene 29 años de edad y tiene una relación de unión libre de la cual tiene un hijo. Desde varios años que se dedica a la distribución y venta de celulares móviles. En esta oportunidad Edson requiere el préstamo para comprar equipos de celulares móviles.  

Edson agradece y valora el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas mensuales.
texts.en: Edson is a member of the “Chaska” communal bank; some of his friends invited him to participate in the communal bank.  Edson was born in the city of Cusco.  He’s 29 years old and is in a common law relationship; he has a son.  He has sold mobile phones for several years.  On this occasion, Edson needs the loan to buy mobile phone equipment.  Edson is grateful for and values the loan and commits to make his monthly payments.

loans.use: to buy mobile phone equipment.

loans.name: Bernadeta

texts.en: Bernadeta is married to Samuel, and they three children.  She has been operating a retail shop in Kitengela for the past year, and earns a monthly profit of KES 10,000. She was introduced to KADET LTD by a friend, and has applied for her first loan of  KES 20,000. She plans to use the money to buy stock for her shop like maize flour, wheat flour, rice, and soft drinks.  She will save the anticipated profits, and hopes to expand her business and open a big wholesale shop in the future.

loans.use: to buy stock for her shop like maize flour, wheat flour, rice, and soft drinks.

loans.name: Florencia

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal  ”VIRGEN PURIFICADA DE TUPAC AMARU;  El banco comunal se encuentra ubicado en el distrito de Urcos en la provincia de Quispicanchis y departamento de Cusco.
La socia es la Sra. Florencia;  La socia tiene 45 años de edad, La socia es casada, La socia tiene 3 hijos de 24, 22, 18 meses; La socia trabaja comprando y vendiendo ropa, zapatillas, zapatos; la socia viaja a Tacna para traer su mercadería, la socia desea el crédito para invertir en la compra de ropa y zapatos y en su viaje; la socia viajara para la ciudad de Tacna y traerá ropa al por mayor, zapatos aprovechando la navidad y que sus amistades y clientas le han hecho pedidos. La socia solicita el préstamo para invertir en la compra de ropa y zapatos.

La socia agradece el préstamo y se compromete  a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas de acuerdo al cronograma de pagos.
texts.en:
Florencia, 45, is a member of the “Virgen Purificada de Tupac Amaru” communal bank located in Urcos District in Quispicanchis Province and Cusco Department.

She is married and has three children who are 24, 22 years and 18 months old.  She works as a clothing, sandal and shoe merchant.  She travels to Tacna to get her merchandise.  She wants the loan to buy clothes and shoes and to pay for her trip.  She will travel to Tacna and will buy clothes and shoes at wholesale taking advantage of Christmas because her acquaintances and customers have placed orders with her.  She is asking for the loan to buy clothes and shoes.

She is grateful for the loan and commits to make her installment payments according to the payment schedule.

loans.use: to buy clothes and shoes.

loans.name: Dinora Cecilia

texts.es:
Dinora, Esta solicitando nuevamente un préstamo, para la compra de insumos agrícolas, pues ella continua en sus labores de siembra de hortalizas, comprara semilla y abono, para sus cultivos, ha tenido una buena experiencia en el manejo de estos préstamos, por eso está satisfecha y continuara siendo cliente.
Su familia ha sido beneficiada con este aporte, ya que la producción le ayuda a generar ingresos para ella, cubriendo los gastos y necesidades de su familia.
texts.en: Dinora is once again requesting a loan to buy farm supplies since she is still working planning vegetables.  She will buy seeds and manure for her crops.  She’s had a good experience managing these loans so is satisfied and will continue being a client.  Her family has benefitted from this contribution since production helps her generate income for her covering expenses and family needs.

loans.use: to buy seeds and manure.

loans.name: Bernard

texts.en:
Bernard is a 69 year old businessman. He is married to Sarah, who is a farmer. They are blessed with one child, aged 25. 

Bernard has been running a retail shop for the past three years. He uses his monthly income of KES 15,000 to support his family. He is applying for his third loan term from  KADET LTD after repaying the previous loans successfully. He will use the loan to buy more stock of sugar, rice and maize meal for his shop. He will use the anticipated profits from the business to provide his child with a university education. He hopes one day to own a wholesale shop, which will help him to improve his family’s standard of living.

loans.use: To buy more stock of sugar, rice and maize meal for his shop

loans.name: Aida

texts.en:
Aida  lives in  Kampala, Uganda.  She is single and has 5 children, three of whom are in school.  Aida has a business of selling charcoal. She has been in this business for ten years, and she works seven days out of every week. Aida sells her products in a shop, by means of retail. 

Aida has requested for a loan of 1,500,000 Ugandan Shillings from Kiva partner  MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bags of charcoal. The main business challenge(s) for Aida include transportation and thieves.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to become a wholesaler and also to educate her children. Aida lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity but doesn't have access to piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include school fees, medication and feeding the family.

loans.use: to buy more bags of charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Abass

texts.en:
Abass is 34 years-old and married with three children, aged between ten months and ten years. He runs an electrical appliance store in Calabatown, a western area in Freetown, Sierra Leone. One of his children is currently attending school. He has three relatives he takes care of at home. 

He's been in this business for ten years and sells DVDs, televisions, extensions, switches, bulbs, padlocks and cables at his store. He began his business because he wanted to generate enough income to support his family, His business is the only source of income he has. He says that the main challenge to his business is damage to his electrical appliances.

He requested this loan through Kiva partner BRAC Sierra Leone in order to buy more electrical appliances. He says that the extra income from this loan will help him educate his children. In the future, he would like to be a supplier of electrical goods that he can offer at a better price. He is grateful for your support.

loans.use: to purchase more DVDs, televisions, extension and cables.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more clothes for sale

loans.name: Doris Estela

texts.es:
Doris, se ha decidido por un nuevo préstamo, ya que la se acerca la época navideña, y quiere fortalecer el negocio con la compra de pantalones, camisas, ropa interior, esta inversión le ayudara para esta preparada con las mejores prendas de vestir con nuevos estilos.
Los préstamos anteriores han tenido un efecto positivo en su negocio, aumentando la solvencia económica.
texts.en: Doris has decided on a new loan because the Christmas season is approaching and she wants to strengthen the business with the purchase of pants, shorts and underwear.  This investment will help her to be prepared with the best articles of clothing in new styles.  Previous loans have had a positive effect on her business increasing her economic solvency.

loans.use: to buy pants, shirts and underwear.

loans.name: Modesta

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal  ”VIRGEN PURIFICADA DE TUPAC AMARU;  El banco comunal se encuentra ubicado en el distrito de Urcos en la provincia de Quispicanchis y departamento de Cusco.
La socia es la Sra. Modesta;  La socia tiene 51 años de edad, La socia es soltera, La socia tiene 5 hijos los cuales ya son todos ellos independientes; La socia trabaja comprando y vendiendo fruta, la socia compra fruta en la ciudad de Cusco del mercado de abastos Vino Canchon y compra al por mayor y lleva  a vender al departamento de Puerto Maldonado; la socia compra manzanas, uva, pera,  también según la época lleva verduras y choclos a vender en camión y muchas veces al mismo monto en plena selva, la socia se queda allá cerca de 1 mes antes de volver para que no sea mucho trajín el ir y volver debido a las distancias. La socia desea invertir el préstamo en la compra de frutas en esta época y llevar a vender su mercadería.

La socia agradece el préstamo y se compromete  a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas de acuerdo al cronograma de pagos.
texts.en:
Modesta, 51, is a member of the “Virgen Purificada de Tupac Amaru” communal bank located in Urcos District in Quispicanchis Province and Cusco Department.

She is single and has five children who are all independent now.  She works as a fruit merchant.  She buys fruit in the city of Cusco’s Vino Canchon foodstuffs market at wholesale and then takes it to sell in Puerto Maldonado Department.  She buys apples, grapes, pears and according to the season also takes vegetables and dehydrated potatoes by bus to sell in the jungle.  She stays there for about a month before returning to minimize the coming and going due to the distance.  She wants to invest the loan in the purchase of seasonal fruit and to take her merchandise to sell.  She is grateful for the loan and commits to make her installment payments according to the payment schedule.

loans.use: to buy seasonal fruit.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy oranges, sour oranges and lemons.
